awd_titl_txt: NeTS:  Small: Modeling and Analysis of Multilayer Jamming Games in Wireless Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Wireless technology has become indispensible in today?s world. However, jamming attacks are a prominent problem, resulting in loss of network availability, increased latency and reduced throughput due to significant deterioration of link quality. The interplay between users and jammers is a natural fit for game-theoretic analysis which provides strategic solutions to the jamming problem and allows us to study the extent to which jammers affect the stability and welfare of the wireless network. 

This project models the impact of local jammers on higher level network functions such as traffic flows and congestion. The PIs provide formulations and solve zero-sum and other games at physical and network layers that reflect appropriate utility/cost functions, jammer and transceiver resource constraints and common knowledge (e.g. side information about channel conditions). Leveraging metrics from algorithmic game theory, such as the price of stability/anarchy, novel metrics and analytical techniques will be developed that measure the impact of jamming such as the Price of Jamming, which measures how much worse equilibria can get when jammers are involved. The PIs also examine the existence of networks, games and utility functions which lead to paradoxical situations (Paradox of Jamming), where jammers may actually improve the welfare of the system. Thus, this work will provide broad insights into determining the extent of jamming damage in wireless networks and also to design appropriate anti-jamming mechanisms. The outcomes of this research will be disseminated through publications, talks, and courses. Traditionally underrepresented minority students in the PIs research groups will actively participate in this research.

In this proposal we investigated security aspects of networks that involve wireless jamming. We explored the vulnerabilities of wireless networks from a game-theoretic point of view. The interplay between users and jammers is a natural fit for game-theoretic analysis as it provides the necessary mathematical tools and methods to study the extent to which jammers affect the stability and welfare of the wireless network. While stability is affected at different layers of the network hierarchy, we focused on the physical and network layers where jamming has the most significant impact.

At the physical layer we modeled the interactions between transceivers and jammers as games between opponents with orthogonal transmission objectives (eg. rates, throughputs etc.). At the network layer, we examined the stability of networks derived from routing games where rational uncooperative users choose routes in the presence of jammers. Leveraging metrics such as the price of stability/anarchy, we proposed the development of novel metrics to measure the impact of jamming such as the Price of Jamming, which measures how much worse equilibria can get when jammers are involved. We also proposed to investigate the existence of networks, games and utility functions which lead to paradoxical situations (Paradox of Jamming), where jammers may actually improve the welfare of the system.

The proposed game-theoretic study aimed to provide insights for determining the extent of the jamming damage and also to design appropriate anti-jamming mechanisms. The novelty of our research lies in the modeling of strategic rational jammers via games and in analyzing these games not in an isolated fashion but by explicitly accounting for the interaction between the physical and network layers via appropriate system parameters. Below we summarize our findings in the physical and network layers.

Physical Layer

The first problem we have looked is scheduling and admission control of incoming multicast traffic with different priority levels. In this part of the work, we presented the analytical framework and characteristics of the optimal call admission and preemption control for a trunked radio system modeled as a finite-source loss system. We considered two classes of users, namely, of high and low priority. We showed that the optimal low priority (LP) call admission policy is a state dependent threshold based policy. Also as a further contribution, we provided the sufficient cost conditions for which the LP call admission and preemption are inevitable, i.e., always optimal, independent of the system state. Finally, we demonstrated using numerical results that the optimal LP call preemption policy in a finite source loss system is a threshold based policy. In a broader context, we studied the optimal service allocation for a finite-source queueing system.

In the second problem we investigated the optimal allocation of frequency spectrum to accommodate the losses in both contention at MAC layer and congestion in network layer. More specifically, we presented a novel model for multiple access systems that jointly models the access-control and communication layers. A joint quantification of both losses is necessary because the performance of one layer directly impacts that of the other one, and thus, both these layers are inseparable.
